summary: Neuroblastoma is a type of cancer that forms in certain types of nerve tissue, most frequently starting from one of the adrenal glands but can also develop in the head, neck, chest, abdomen, or spine. It is the most common cancer in babies and the third-most common cancer in children.
causes: Genetic mutation occurring in the first trimester of pregnancy
Germline mutations in the anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) gene
Germline mutations in the PHOX2B gene
Germline mutations in the KIF1B gene
Duplicated segments of the LMO1 gene
Copy-number variation within the NBPF10 gene
Excessively expressed miRNAs in 1p-deleted neuroblastoma cells
risk_factors: Parental factors around conception and during gestation
Occupation (exposure to chemicals in specific industries)
Use of medicinal drugs during pregnancy
Exposure to infection early in life
Use of hormones and fertility drugs
symptoms: Lump in the abdomen, neck, or chest
Painless, bluish lump under the skin
Inability to stand, crawl, or walk
diagnosis: Elevated levels of catecholamines or their metabolites in urine or blood (dopamine, homovanillic acid (HVA), vanillylmandelic acid (VMA))
Microscopy (small, round, blue tumor cells, Homer Wright pseudorosettes)
International Neuroblastoma Risk Group (INRG) classification system
International Neuroblastoma Risk Group Staging System (INRGSS)
Imaging tests (x-rays, CT scan, ultrasound, MRI)
treatments: Immunotherapy with anti-GD2 monoclonal antibody therapy (dinutuximab)
High-dose chemotherapy and radiation therapy with stem cell rescue
